vasily-grossman.bio: Soviet journalist and author who wrote 'The Hell of Treblinka' (1944), one of the first accounts of the extermination camp, based on survivor testimonies.

wiktor-tolkin.name: Wiktor Tołkin
wiktor-tolkin.bio: Polish architect who designed the monumental Mausoleum and memorial at Majdanek in 1969, creating one of Poland's most striking Holocaust memorials.

edward-balawejder.name: Edward Balawejder
edward-balawejder.bio: Served as director of the Majdanek State Museum, contributing to the documentation and preservation of the camp's history and physical remains.

jonathan-ornstein-jcc2.name: Jonathan Ornstein
jonathan-ornstein-jcc2.bio: American-born leader who founded and directs JCC Kraków, a flagship institution in the post-Holocaust revival of Jewish communal life in Poland.

affiliations.organization: Jewish Community Centre of Krakow (JCC Kraków)

henryk-halkowski.name: Henryk Halkowski
henryk-halkowski.bio: Polish Jewish intellectual and translator who was a key figure in the revival of Jewish cultural life in Kraków and an early advisor to Jewish community institutions.

affiliations.organization: Jewish Community Centre of Krakow (JCC Kraków)

tadeusz-jakubowicz.name: Tadeusz Jakubowicz
tadeusz-jakubowicz.bio: Longtime chairman of the Jewish Community of Kraków (Gmina), working closely with JCC Kraków to support the revitalization of Jewish life in the city.

affiliations.organization: Jewish Community Centre of Krakow (JCC Kraków)

szymon-zajczyk.name: Szymon Zajczyk
szymon-zajczyk.bio: Polish Jewish art historian who documented and studied the Tykocin Synagogue before World War II, contributing to the record of its 17th-century baroque architecture.

tomasz-wisniewski.name: Tomasz Wiśniewski
tomasz-wisniewski.bio: Polish historian and filmmaker from Białystok who has extensively documented the Jewish heritage of Tykocin and the surrounding Podlasie region.

izaak-rabinowicz.name: Izaak Rabinowicz
izaak-rabinowicz.bio: Served as one of the notable rabbis of Tykocin's Jewish community, which flourished from the 16th century until its destruction in the Holocaust.

barbara-kirshenblatt-gimblett-ap.name: Barbara Kirshenblatt-Gimblett
barbara-kirshenblatt-gimblett-ap.bio: NYU professor emerita who shaped POLIN's core exhibition and continues to advise on its additional programs exploring the full scope of Polish Jewish civilization.

affiliations.organization: Museum of the History of Polish Jews (POLIN) - additional programs

marian-turski-ap.name: Marian Turski
marian-turski-ap.bio: Holocaust survivor and honorary chairman of the POLIN Museum Association who actively supports the museum's expanding educational and cultural programs.

affiliations.organization: Museum of the History of Polish Jews (POLIN) - additional programs

kamil-kijek.name: Kamil Kijek
kamil-kijek.bio: Polish historian at the University of Wrocław who has contributed to POLIN's research and academic programs on the history of Jews in Poland.

affiliations.organization: Museum of the History of Polish Jews (POLIN) - additional programs

piotr-wislicki.name: Piotr Wiślicki
piotr-wislicki.bio: Chairman of the Foundation for the Preservation of Jewish Heritage in Poland and chairman of the Association of the Jewish Historical Institute, a leading advocate for Polish Jewish heritage.

affiliations.organization: Foundation for the Preservation of Jewish Heritage in Poland

anna-kubiak.name: Anna Kubiak
anna-kubiak.bio: Manages heritage preservation programs at FODZ, coordinating the restoration and documentation of hundreds of Jewish heritage sites across Poland.

affiliations.organization: Foundation for the Preservation of Jewish Heritage in Poland

pawel-spiewak.name: Paweł Śpiewak
pawel-spiewak.bio: Polish sociologist and political philosopher who served as director of the Jewish Historical Institute in Warsaw, overseeing its renowned Ringelblum Archive and research programs.

eleonora-bergman.name: Eleonora Bergman
eleonora-bergman.bio: Architectural historian who served as deputy director of the Jewish Historical Institute, specializing in the history of synagogue architecture in Poland.

tidjane-thiam.name: Tidjane Thiam
tidjane-thiam.bio: Franco-Ivorian businessman who served as CEO of Credit Suisse, leading a major restructuring before his departure amid a corporate espionage scandal.

thomas-gottstein.name: Thomas Gottstein
thomas-gottstein.bio: Swiss banker who served as the last standalone CEO of Credit Suisse before its emergency acquisition by UBS in 2023.

axel-lehmann.name: Axel Lehmann
axel-lehmann.bio: Swiss executive who served as chairman of Credit Suisse during its final crisis, overseeing the bank's emergency merger with UBS in March 2023.

colm-kelleher.name: Colm Kelleher
colm-kelleher.bio: Irish-American banker serving as chairman of UBS, guiding the integration of Credit Suisse into UBS following the historic 2023 acquisition.

henri-nestle.name: Henri Nestlé
henri-nestle.bio: German-born Swiss confectioner and pharmacist who founded Nestlé in 1866, originally developing an infant cereal food that launched the global food company.

flavia-bustreo.name: Flavia Bustreo
flavia-bustreo.bio: Italian physician who served as WHO Assistant Director-General for Family, Women's and Children's Health, engaging with Israeli medical innovations and partnerships.

ruth-arnon.name: Ruth Arnon
ruth-arnon.bio: Renowned Israeli immunologist and former president of the Israel Academy of Sciences who has served on WHO advisory committees, linking Israeli research to global health policy.

herbert-winter.name: Herbert Winter
herbert-winter.bio: Led SIG as president, advocating for the Swiss Jewish community on issues including Holocaust-era assets, antisemitism, and communal welfare.

sigi-feigel.name: Sigi Feigel
sigi-feigel.bio: Prominent Swiss Jewish leader who served as honorary president of the Israelite Community of Zurich and was a key figure in Swiss Jewish advocacy for decades.

ralph-lewin-sf.name: Ralph Lewin
ralph-lewin-sf.bio: Current president of the Swiss Federation of Jewish Communities (SIG/FSCI), the umbrella organization representing Jewish communities across Switzerland.

herbert-winter-sf.name: Herbert Winter
herbert-winter-sf.bio: Served as president of SIG/FSCI, leading Swiss Jewish communal advocacy on issues including security, interfaith relations, and Holocaust remembrance.

jonathan-kreutner.name: Jonathan Kreutner
jonathan-kreutner.bio: Serves as secretary general of SIG/FSCI, managing the federation's day-to-day operations and public communications on behalf of Swiss Jewry.

jean-francois-bergier.name: Jean-François Bergier
jean-francois-bergier.bio: Swiss economic historian who chaired the Independent Commission of Experts Switzerland–Second World War (1996–2002), producing the landmark report on Swiss dealings with Nazi Germany.

georg-kreis.name: Georg Kreis
georg-kreis.bio: Swiss historian and professor at the University of Basel who served on the Bergier Commission, contributing research on Swiss refugee policy during World War II.

jacques-picard.name: Jacques Picard
jacques-picard.bio: Swiss historian who served on the Bergier Commission and authored key studies on the fate of Jewish assets in Swiss banks during and after the Holocaust.

cornelio-sommaruga.name: Cornelio Sommaruga
cornelio-sommaruga.bio: Swiss diplomat who served as ICRC president and later acknowledged the ICRC's failures during the Holocaust, engaging in dialogue with Jewish organizations about institutional responsibility.

affiliations.organization: International Committee of the Red Cross (Jewish relationship)

mirjana-spoljaric.name: Mirjana Spoljaric Egger
mirjana-spoljaric.bio: Current ICRC president, the first woman to hold the role, continuing institutional engagement with Jewish communities on humanitarian and historical reconciliation issues.

affiliations.organization: International Committee of the Red Cross (Jewish relationship)

charles-kaufman.name: Charles O. Kaufman
charles-kaufman.bio: Served as international president of B'nai B'rith, the world's oldest Jewish service organization, guiding its global programs and UN-level advocacy.

borge-brende.name: Børge Brende
borge-brende.bio: Former Norwegian foreign minister serving as president of the World Economic Forum, managing its daily operations and annual meetings.

hilde-schwab.name: Hilde Schwab
hilde-schwab.bio: Co-founder of the World Economic Forum alongside her husband Klaus Schwab, and founder of the Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship.

david-hatchwell.name: David Hatchwell
david-hatchwell.bio: Prominent Spanish Jewish businessman and communal leader who serves in the leadership of FCJE and is active in promoting Jewish life and culture in Spain.

affiliations.organization: Federación de Comunidades Judías de España (FCJE)

miguel-angel-garcia-alcala.name: Miguel Ángel García
miguel-angel-garcia-alcala.bio: Coordinates the Network of Jewish Quarters of Spain (Red de Juderías), an association of cities preserving and promoting their historic Jewish heritage districts.

antonio-lopez-de-toledo.name: Antonio López
antonio-lopez-de-toledo.bio: Has directed heritage tourism initiatives within the Red de Juderías, developing the 'Caminos de Sefarad' routes connecting historic Jewish quarters across Spain.

isaac-querub-rj.name: Isaac Querub
isaac-querub-rj.bio: As president of the FCJE, advises the Red de Juderías on Jewish cultural authenticity and historical accuracy in its heritage preservation projects.

isaac-querub-shb.name: Isaac Querub
isaac-querub-shb.bio: As president of Spain's Jewish federation, supports the work of Sephardic cultural institutions including the Sephardic House of Barcelona.

dominique-tomasov-blinder.name: Dominique Tomasov Blinder
dominique-tomasov-blinder.bio: Active in Barcelona's Jewish cultural scene, organizing events and programs related to Sephardic heritage and Jewish life in Catalonia.

diego-de-ojeda.name: Diego de Ojeda
diego-de-ojeda.bio: Spanish diplomat who served as the first director of Casa Sefarad-Israel (now Centro Sefarad-Israel), establishing its role as a cultural bridge between Spain and the Jewish world.

esther-bendahan-csi.name: Esther Bendahán
esther-bendahan-csi.bio: Spanish Jewish writer who directs cultural and literary programming at Centro Sefarad-Israel, promoting Sephardic heritage and Spanish-Jewish cultural exchange.

diego-de-ojeda-cs.name: Diego de Ojeda
diego-de-ojeda-cs.bio: Spanish diplomat who served as founding director of Casa Sefarad, establishing it as a diplomatic and cultural center for Spanish-Jewish and Spanish-Israeli relations.

miguel-de-lucas-cs.name: Miguel de Lucas
miguel-de-lucas-cs.bio: Current director overseeing Casa Sefarad's programs on Sephardic heritage, Spanish-Israeli cultural exchange, and interfaith dialogue.

isaac-querub-cs.name: Isaac Querub
isaac-querub-cs.bio: As head of Spain's Jewish federation, serves as a key communal partner for Casa Sefarad's events and programs on Jewish life in Spain.

ana-maria-lopez-alvarez.name: Ana María López Álvarez
ana-maria-lopez-alvarez.bio: Served as director of the Museo Sefardí and authored key publications on the Sephardic heritage collections and the history of the El Tránsito Synagogue.

isaac-querub-ad.name: Isaac Querub
isaac-querub-ad.bio: Longtime president of the FCJE who has led efforts to strengthen Jewish communal infrastructure in Spain and promote the 2015 Sephardic citizenship law.

affiliations.organization: Federation of Jewish Communities of Spain (additional)

david-hatchwell-ad.name: David Hatchwell
david-hatchwell-ad.bio: Spanish Jewish businessman and philanthropist active in FCJE leadership, supporting Jewish cultural and educational initiatives across Spain.

affiliations.organization: Federation of Jewish Communities of Spain (additional)

albert-cohen-ad.name: Albert Cohen
albert-cohen-ad.bio: Active leader in Spain's Jewish communal life who has served in FCJE governance, representing Jewish communities in national affairs and Sephardic heritage promotion.

affiliations.organization: Federation of Jewish Communities of Spain (additional)

santiago-palomero-msh.name: Santiago Palomero Plaza
santiago-palomero-msh.bio: Archaeologist directing the Museum of Sephardic Heritage in Toledo's historic El Tránsito Synagogue, overseeing its collections on medieval Spanish Jewish life.

ana-maria-lopez-alvarez-msh.name: Ana María López Álvarez
ana-maria-lopez-alvarez-msh.bio: Former museum director who contributed extensively to research and publication on Sephardic material culture and the history of the Toledo Jewish community.

uriel-macias-kapon.name: Uriel Macías Kapón
uriel-macias-kapon.bio: Spanish scholar and publisher specializing in Sephardic studies who has collaborated with the museum on publications and exhibitions about Sephardic heritage.

yitzhak-bar-sheshet.name: Isaac bar Sheshet Perfet
yitzhak-bar-sheshet.bio: Renowned medieval rabbi who served the Córdoba Jewish community, one of the great Talmudic authorities of 14th-century Spain.

maimonides.name: Moses Maimonides
maimonides.bio: Born in Córdoba, Maimonides was the preeminent medieval Jewish philosopher, physician, and Torah scholar whose legacy is deeply intertwined with the city's Jewish heritage.

jesus-pelaez-del-rosal.name: Jesús Peláez del Rosal
jesus-pelaez-del-rosal.bio: Spanish professor and president of the Asociación de Amigos de Sefarad who has contributed to the study and preservation of Córdoba's Jewish heritage sites.

miguel-de-lucas-csim.name: Miguel de Lucas
miguel-de-lucas-csim.bio: Director of Casa Sefarad-Israel in Madrid, leading its mission as a diplomatic and cultural center promoting Sephardic heritage and Spanish-Israeli relations.

diego-de-ojeda-csim.name: Diego de Ojeda
diego-de-ojeda-csim.bio: Diplomat who established Casa Sefarad-Israel in Madrid under Spain's Ministry of Foreign Affairs, creating a unique institution bridging Spanish and Jewish worlds.

esther-bendahan-csim.name: Esther Bendahán
esther-bendahan-csim.bio: Writer and cultural director at Casa Sefarad-Israel Madrid who curates programs on Sephardic literature, culture, and the ongoing relationship between Spain and its Jewish heritage.

santiago-palomero-ms.name: Santiago Palomero Plaza
santiago-palomero-ms.bio: Archaeologist and museum professional serving as director of the Museo Sefardí in Toledo, managing Spain's national museum of Sephardic culture and history.

ana-maria-lopez-alvarez-ms.name: Ana María López Álvarez
ana-maria-lopez-alvarez-ms.bio: Led the Museo Sefardí and contributed important scholarship on the museum's collection of Sephardic ceremonial objects and medieval Hebrew inscriptions.

amparo-alvarez.name: Amparo Álvarez
amparo-alvarez.bio: Curator at the Museo Sefardí who has overseen exhibitions and conservation of the museum's collection within the historic El Tránsito Synagogue.

david-schizer.name: David Schizer
david-schizer.bio: Former Columbia Law School dean serving as CEO of JDC, overseeing its humanitarian and community development programs in over 70 countries.

affiliations.organization: JDC (American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee) - Global

alan-gill.name: Alan Gill
alan-gill.bio: Served as CEO of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, leading its global operations in Jewish community support and disaster relief.

affiliations.organization: JDC (American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee) - Global

penny-blumenstein.name: Penny Blumenstein
penny-blumenstein.bio: Philanthropist and communal leader serving as chair of JDC's board, guiding the organization's strategic direction in global Jewish humanitarian work.

affiliations.organization: JDC (American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee) - Global

joseph-hyman.name: Joseph C. Hyman
joseph-hyman.bio: Served as executive vice chairman of JDC during World War II and its aftermath, managing massive rescue and relief operations for European Jewry.

affiliations.organization: JDC (American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee) - Global

yossi-klein-halevi.name: Yossi Klein Halevi
yossi-klein-halevi.bio: American-Israeli journalist and author of 'Letters to My Palestinian Neighbor' who serves as a senior fellow at the Hartman Institute, focusing on Muslim-Jewish relations.

doron-perez.name: Rabbi Doron Perez
doron-perez.bio: South African-born Israeli rabbi serving as executive chairman of World Mizrachi, the global Religious Zionist movement, revitalizing its programs and public presence.

yitzhak-yaakov-reines.name: Rabbi Yitzhak Yaakov Reines
yitzhak-yaakov-reines.bio: Lithuanian rabbi who founded the Mizrachi movement in 1902 in Vilna, establishing Religious Zionism as a major stream within the World Zionist Organization.

rabbanit-shani-taragin.name: Rabbanit Shani Taragin
rabbanit-shani-taragin.bio: Serves as educational director at World Mizrachi, leading its Torah education programs and scholar-in-residence initiatives in communities worldwide.

phyllis-greenberg-heideman.name: Phyllis Greenberg Heideman
phyllis-greenberg-heideman.bio: Serves as president of the International March of the Living, overseeing the annual program that has brought hundreds of thousands of participants to Auschwitz on Yom HaShoah.

aharon-tamir.name: Aharon Tamir
aharon-tamir.bio: Israeli co-founder who helped establish the March of the Living, developing its educational framework linking Holocaust remembrance to the vitality of the State of Israel.

nota-schiller.name: Rabbi Nota Schiller
nota-schiller.bio: American-born rabbi who co-founded Ohr Somayach in Jerusalem in 1970, building it into one of the world's leading outreach yeshivas for Jews exploring their heritage.

mendel-weinbach.name: Rabbi Mendel Weinbach
mendel-weinbach.bio: Co-founded Ohr Somayach alongside Rabbi Nota Schiller and served as co-dean for over four decades, authoring numerous works on Talmud and Jewish thought.

yaakov-asher-sinclair.name: Rabbi Yaakov Asher Sinclair
yaakov-asher-sinclair.bio: British-born rabbi and author who serves as a senior lecturer at Ohr Somayach and is known for his weekly Torah publication and educational outreach.

julius-berman.name: Julius Berman
julius-berman.bio: American attorney and Jewish communal leader serving as chairman of the Claims Conference, overseeing its governance and policy on Holocaust-era property restitution.

affiliations.organization: Claims Conference (Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany)

greg-schneider.name: Greg Schneider
greg-schneider.bio: Serves as executive vice president of the Claims Conference, managing its operations including the distribution of billions of dollars in compensation to Holocaust survivors.

affiliations.organization: Claims Conference (Conference on Jewish Material Claims Against Germany)

greg-kay.name: Greg Kay
greg-kay.bio: Australian-born executive serving as director general of Keren Hayesod, managing its fundraising campaigns across over 45 countries to support immigration and social programs in Israel.

abraham-menachem-ussishkin.name: Abraham Menachem Ussishkin
abraham-menachem-ussishkin.bio: Russian-born Zionist leader who served as the first chairman of Keren Hayesod when it was established at the London Zionist Conference in 1920 to fund the Jewish national home.

sholom-lipskar.name: Rabbi Sholom Lipskar
sholom-lipskar.bio: Chabad rabbi who founded the Aleph Institute in 1981 to provide religious and humanitarian support to Jewish military personnel and prisoners in the United States.

gary-apfel.name: Gary Apfel
gary-apfel.bio: Attorney and former Aleph Institute vice president who has advocated for criminal justice reform and compassionate sentencing through the organization's legal programs.

arik-zeevi.name: Arik Ze'evi
arik-zeevi.bio: Israeli Olympic judoka and bronze medalist who serves as president of Maccabi World Union, the global umbrella organization of the Maccabi sports movement.

pierre-gildesgame.name: Pierre Gildesgame
pierre-gildesgame.bio: British-Jewish sports administrator who served as longtime president of Maccabi World Union and was instrumental in establishing the Maccabiah Games as a major international sporting event.

yosef-yekutieli.name: Yosef Yekutieli
yosef-yekutieli.bio: Russian-born Israeli athlete and visionary who proposed and organized the first Maccabiah Games in 1932, establishing the 'Jewish Olympics' in British Mandate Palestine.

michael-papo.name: Michael Papo
michael-papo.bio: Served as executive director of Limmud International, coordinating the global network of volunteer-led Jewish learning communities.

yehuda-bauer.name: Yehuda Bauer
yehuda-bauer.bio: Israeli Holocaust historian and professor emeritus at Hebrew University who served as founding academic advisor to the IHRA (formerly ITF), shaping its educational mission.

mark-weitzman.name: Mark Weitzman
mark-weitzman.bio: Serves as chair of IHRA's Committee on Antisemitism and Holocaust Denial, playing a key role in developing the IHRA working definition of antisemitism.

kathrin-meyer.name: Kathrin Meyer
kathrin-meyer.bio: German diplomat and historian serving as secretary general of IHRA, coordinating the intergovernmental body's work on Holocaust education, remembrance, and research across its member states.

noah-weinberg.name: Rabbi Noah Weinberg
noah-weinberg.bio: American-born Israeli rabbi who founded Aish HaTorah in 1974 in Jerusalem's Old City, building it into one of the largest Jewish outreach organizations in the world.

steven-burg.name: Rabbi Steven Burg
steven-burg.bio: Serves as CEO of Aish HaTorah, leading the global Jewish educational and outreach organization with centers in dozens of countries.

ephraim-shore.name: Ephraim Shore
ephraim-shore.bio: Led the development of Aish.com, one of the largest Jewish content websites, expanding Aish HaTorah's educational mission into the digital space.

shmuel-rosenman-iml.name: Shmuel Rosenman
shmuel-rosenman-iml.bio: Israeli educator who created the International March of the Living in 1988, establishing the annual Holocaust remembrance march from Auschwitz to Birkenau on Yom HaShoah.

phyllis-greenberg-heideman-iml.name: Phyllis Greenberg Heideman
phyllis-greenberg-heideman-iml.bio: American communal leader serving as president of the International March of the Living, overseeing participation from over 40 countries in the annual program.

eli-rubenstein.name: Eli Rubenstein
eli-rubenstein.bio: Longtime national director of March of the Living Canada and co-author of 'Witness: Passing the Torch of Holocaust Memory,' a leading educator in the program's global network.

gillian-tans.name: Gillian Tans
gillian-tans.bio: Dutch businesswoman who served as CEO of Booking.com from 2016 to 2019, having joined the company in 2002 and risen through its leadership ranks.

geert-jan-bruinsma.name: Geert-Jan Bruinsma
geert-jan-bruinsma.bio: Dutch entrepreneur who founded Bookings.nl in 1996, the online hotel reservation startup that evolved into the global travel platform Booking.com.

kees-koolen.name: Kees Koolen
kees-koolen.bio: Early CEO of Booking.com who led the company during its critical growth phase before its acquisition by Priceline Group in 2005.

ronny-naftaniel-niw.name: Ronny Naftaniel
ronny-naftaniel-niw.bio: Prominent Dutch-Jewish communal leader and former director of CIDI who has contributed to the NIW as a leading voice on antisemitism and Jewish affairs in the Netherlands.

hans-knoop.name: Hans Knoop
hans-knoop.bio: Dutch-Jewish investigative journalist known for exposing Dutch Nazi collaborator Pieter Menten in the 1970s, who contributed to Dutch Jewish media.

philip-mechanicus.name: Philip Mechanicus
philip-mechanicus.bio: Dutch-Jewish journalist who wrote for various Amsterdam newspapers and kept a diary in Westerbork transit camp that became a key Holocaust document.

judith-belinfante.name: Judith Belinfante
judith-belinfante.bio: Pioneering museum director who oversaw the reopening and transformation of the Joods Historisch Museum in 1987 in a restored Ashkenazi synagogue complex.

julie-marthe-cohen.name: Julie-Marthe Cohen
julie-marthe-cohen.bio: Expert in Jewish ceremonial art and material culture who has served as chief curator at the Joods Historisch Museum, shaping its exhibitions and collections.

joel-cahen.name: Joel Cahen
joel-cahen.bio: Former staff member at the Joods Historisch Museum who later founded Jewish heritage digital initiatives and contributed to online Jewish museum projects.

ron-van-der-wieken.name: Ron van der Wieken
ron-van-der-wieken.bio: Dutch-Jewish communal leader who chaired the Centraal Joods Overleg, the umbrella body coordinating Jewish organizational representation in the Netherlands.

ruben-vis-cjo.name: Ruben Vis
ruben-vis-cjo.bio: Served in administrative roles within the CJO while also holding leadership positions in the NIK, coordinating Dutch Jewish communal affairs.

hanna-luden.name: Hanna Luden
hanna-luden.bio: Served as director of CIDI (Centre for Information and Documentation on Israel) and participated in CJO coordination of Dutch Jewish community advocacy.

binyomin-jacobs-nik.name: Binyomin Jacobs
binyomin-jacobs-nik.bio: Senior Orthodox rabbinical authority of the Netherlands, serving as inter-provincial chief rabbi under the NIK framework for Dutch Ashkenazi congregations.

lody-van-de-kamp.name: Lody van de Kamp
lody-van-de-kamp.bio: Dutch Orthodox rabbi affiliated with the NIK who became widely known as a media personality and commentator on Jewish life and culture in the Netherlands.

raphael-evers.name: Raphael Evers
raphael-evers.bio: Dutch rabbi who served within the NIK rabbinate, known for his scholarly publications on Jewish philosophy and his contributions to Dutch Jewish religious education.

isaac-aboab-da-fonseca.name: Isaac Aboab da Fonseca
isaac-aboab-da-fonseca.bio: Hakham of the Amsterdam Portuguese community and considered the first appointed rabbi in the Americas during his time in Dutch Brazil.

manasseh-ben-israel.name: Manasseh Ben Israel
manasseh-ben-israel.bio: Renowned Portuguese-Jewish rabbi and scholar of the Amsterdam community who petitioned Oliver Cromwell for the readmission of Jews to England in 1655.

pinhas-toledano.name: Pinhas Toledano
pinhas-toledano.bio: Served as chief rabbi of the Portuguese-Israelite community of Amsterdam, maintaining the Sephardic liturgical and rabbinical traditions of the historic congregation.

otto-frank.name: Otto Frank
otto-frank.bio: Father of Anne Frank and sole surviving member of the immediate Frank family, who established the Anne Frank House museum in 1957 to preserve his daughter's legacy.

ronald-leopold.name: Ronald Leopold
ronald-leopold.bio: Museum professional serving as executive director of the Anne Frank House, overseeing its operations as one of the most visited museums in the Netherlands.

hans-westra.name: Hans Westra
hans-westra.bio: Led the Anne Frank House as managing director for many years, expanding its educational programs and international outreach on tolerance and human rights.

judith-belinfante-jhma.name: Judith Belinfante
judith-belinfante-jhma.bio: Museum director who oversaw the 1987 reopening of the Jewish Historical Museum in restored Ashkenazi synagogue buildings as Amsterdam's principal museum of Dutch Jewish life.

julie-marthe-cohen-jhma.name: Julie-Marthe Cohen
julie-marthe-cohen-jhma.bio: Curator specializing in Jewish ceremonial objects and material culture who led the museum's exhibition and collection development programs.

joel-cahen-jhma.name: Joel Cahen
joel-cahen-jhma.bio: Contributed to the Jewish Historical Museum's curatorial work before going on to develop pioneering digital platforms for Jewish cultural heritage.

dirk-mulder.name: Dirk Mulder
dirk-mulder.bio: Longtime director of the Westerbork Memorial Center who developed it into a major Holocaust remembrance and education site in the Netherlands.

jules-schelvis.name: Jules Schelvis
jules-schelvis.bio: Dutch Holocaust survivor deported via Westerbork to Sobibor who later became a leading historian of the transit camp and the Sobibor extermination camp.

guido-abuys.name: Guido Abuys
guido-abuys.bio: Head of collections and research at Camp Westerbork Memorial, responsible for preserving artifacts and historical documentation related to the transit camp.

lody-van-de-kamp-nik.name: Lody van de Kamp
lody-van-de-kamp-nik.bio: Dutch rabbi affiliated with the NIK known for his accessible public commentary on Jewish practices and his contributions to Dutch media and journalism.

raphael-evers-nik.name: Raphael Evers
raphael-evers-nik.bio: Rabbi within the Dutch Orthodox rabbinate who has authored numerous works on Jewish thought and served congregations under the NIK umbrella.

ruben-vis-nik.name: Ruben Vis
ruben-vis-nik.bio: Longtime secretary-general of the NIK, managing the administrative and organizational affairs of the Dutch Ashkenazi Jewish religious community.

frits-barend.name: Frits Barend
frits-barend.bio: Dutch-Jewish television journalist and author whose parents survived the Holocaust, known for his public advocacy for Holocaust remembrance in the Netherlands.

jacques-grishaver.name: Jacques Grishaver
jacques-grishaver.bio: Dutch Holocaust survivor hidden as a child during WWII who became an advocate for Holocaust education and the establishment of the National Holocaust Museum.

johannes-houwink-ten-cate.name: Johannes Houwink ten Cate
johannes-houwink-ten-cate.bio: Dutch historian and professor specializing in the Holocaust in the Netherlands who contributed scholarly expertise to the development of the museum's narrative.

bernardo-gomez.name: Bernardo Gómez
bernardo-gomez.bio: Served as co-CEO of Grupo Televisa, managing the company's broadcasting and content operations for Latin America's dominant Spanish-language media conglomerate.

alfonso-de-angoitia.name: Alfonso de Angoitia
alfonso-de-angoitia.bio: Mexican attorney and executive who served as executive vice president and co-CEO of Grupo Televisa, overseeing its corporate strategy.

emilio-azcarraga-vidaurreta.name: Emilio Azcárraga Vidaurreta
emilio-azcarraga-vidaurreta.bio: Mexican media pioneer who founded the broadcasting empire that became Grupo Televisa, establishing XEW radio and Mexico's first television station.

carlos-slim-domit.name: Carlos Slim Domit
carlos-slim-domit.bio: Eldest son of Carlos Slim Helú who serves as chairman of Grupo Carso and Telmex, continuing the family's leadership of Mexico's largest industrial conglomerate.

patrick-slim-domit.name: Patrick Slim Domit
patrick-slim-domit.bio: Son of Carlos Slim Helú who serves on the boards of various Grupo Carso subsidiaries and oversees key business divisions within the conglomerate.

juan-antonio-perez-simon.name: Juan Antonio Pérez Simón
juan-antonio-perez-simon.bio: Longtime Grupo Carso executive and close associate of Carlos Slim who also became known as one of Latin America's foremost art collectors.

jacobo-zabludovsky.name: Jacobo Zabludovsky
jacobo-zabludovsky.bio: Legendary Mexican television anchor and journalist of Jewish origin who was the foremost news broadcaster in Mexican media history and active in Jewish cultural circles.

enrique-krauze.name: Enrique Krauze
enrique-krauze.bio: Prominent Mexican public intellectual, historian, and publisher of Jewish origin who has contributed to Mexican Jewish cultural discourse and literary life.

margo-glantz.name: Margo Glantz
margo-glantz.bio: Mexican author and literary scholar of Jewish-Ukrainian descent, known for her memoir about Jewish immigrant life in Mexico, active in Jewish cultural organizations.

elias-sourasky.name: Elías Sourasky
elias-sourasky.bio: Mexican-Jewish businessman and philanthropist of Lithuanian origin who was a major benefactor of Jewish communal institutions in Mexico City.

carlos-slim-helu-cdi.name: Moisés Saba Masri
carlos-slim-helu-cdi.bio: Mexican-Jewish billionaire businessman and philanthropist who supported numerous Jewish communal institutions in Mexico including community centers.

marcos-shabot-cdi.name: Marcos Shabot
marcos-shabot-cdi.bio: Prominent Mexican Jewish communal leader who has held leadership positions across multiple Jewish organizations in Mexico City.

salomon-cohen-kadima.name: Salomón Cohen
salomon-cohen-kadima.bio: Leader within Mexico City's Kadima community, which serves Jewish families of Aleppo (Halabi) Syrian origin and is one of the largest Sephardic communities in the Americas.

isaac-hamui.name: Isaac Hamui
isaac-hamui.bio: Served as president of the Kadima community in Mexico City, representing one of the well-organized branches of Mexico's Sephardic Jewish population.

moises-assa-kadima.name: Moisés Assa
moises-assa-kadima.bio: Mexican Jewish communal leader who has held leadership roles in multiple Jewish organizations, contributing to the institutional life of the Sephardic community.

ella-leibovitz.name: Ella Leibovitz
ella-leibovitz.bio: Holocaust survivor and educator who co-founded the Museo Memoria y Tolerancia in Mexico City, dedicating her life to Holocaust education in Latin America.

mario-torroella.name: Mario Torroella Caballero
mario-torroella.bio: Museum professional who has served in leadership at the Museo Memoria y Tolerancia, overseeing its exhibitions and educational programs on genocide and human rights.

dalia-zaga.name: Dalia Zaga
dalia-zaga.bio: Has contributed to the museum's educational and cultural programming alongside founder Sharon Zaga, developing outreach initiatives on tolerance and social responsibility.

moises-assa.name: Moisés Assa
moises-assa.bio: Served as president of the Comité Central de la Comunidad Judía de México, the central representative body of Mexico's approximately 50,000-strong Jewish community.

affiliations.organization: Comité Central de la Comunidad Judía de México

renee-dayan-shabot.name: Renée Dayan Shabot
renee-dayan-shabot.bio: Mexican-Jewish historian and communal leader who has documented Mexican Jewish history and served in leadership roles including at Tribuna Israelita.

affiliations.organization: Comité Central de la Comunidad Judía de México

salomon-alfie-cc.name: Salomón Alfie
salomon-alfie-cc.bio: Mexican Jewish communal figure who has held leadership positions in the organized Jewish community of Mexico, contributing to its institutional governance.

affiliations.organization: Comité Central de la Comunidad Judía de México

sion-cohen-chmgd.name: Sión Cohen
sion-cohen-chmgd.bio: Leader within the Colegio Hebreo Maguen David, one of Mexico City's premier Jewish schools serving the Syrian Sephardic community with bilingual education.

isaac-saad.name: Isaac Saad
isaac-saad.bio: Mexican-Jewish communal figure connected to the Maguen David institutions serving Mexico City's large Damascene Jewish community.

esther-hamui-halabe.name: Esther Hamui Halabe
esther-hamui-halabe.bio: Mexican academic and sociologist of Syrian-Jewish descent who has researched and documented the educational and communal life of Mexican Sephardic Jewry.

renee-dayan-shabot-ti.name: Renée Dayan Shabot
renee-dayan-shabot-ti.bio: Mexican-Jewish historian and communal leader who directed Tribuna Israelita for years, promoting interfaith dialogue and combating antisemitism in Mexico.

sergio-nudelstejer.name: Sergio Nudelstejer
sergio-nudelstejer.bio: Served as director of Tribuna Israelita, leading the organization's mission to represent Jewish community perspectives in Mexican public discourse.

mauricio-lulka.name: Mauricio Lulka
mauricio-lulka.bio: Mexican-Jewish communal leader involved in Tribuna Israelita's efforts to promote understanding between the Jewish community and broader Mexican society.

maricruz-arrubarrena.name: Maricruz Arrubarrena
maricruz-arrubarrena.bio: Served as chief operating officer of KidZania, helping scale the interactive children's entertainment concept from Mexico City to over 25 locations worldwide.

fernando-pardo.name: Fernando Pardo
fernando-pardo.bio: Executive who has served in KidZania's senior leadership, helping manage the company's global expansion of its children's role-playing theme park concept.

carlos-slim-domit-kz.name: Carlos Slim Domit
carlos-slim-domit-kz.bio: As chairman of Grupo Carso, has been connected to investment interests in KidZania, which originated in Mexico City's Santa Fe district in 1999.

marcos-shabot-cc.name: Marcos Shabot
marcos-shabot-cc.bio: Has served as president of the central committee representing Mexico's Jewish community, coordinating communal affairs and external relations.

affiliations.organization: Comite Central de la Comunidad Judia de Mexico

moises-assa-cc.name: Moisés Assa
moises-assa-cc.bio: Prominent Mexican Jewish communal leader who served as president of the organized Jewish community structure in Mexico City.

affiliations.organization: Comite Central de la Comunidad Judia de Mexico

renee-dayan-cc.name: Renée Dayan Shabot
renee-dayan-cc.bio: Historian and communal leader who has served Mexican Jewish organizations in advocacy and documentation of Jewish community life in Mexico.

affiliations.organization: Comite Central de la Comunidad Judia de Mexico

monika-pessler.name: Monika Pessler
monika-pessler.bio: Art historian and museum director who has led the Sigmund Freud Museum in Vienna, overseeing its major renovation and expansion completed in 2020.

anna-freud.name: Anna Freud
anna-freud.bio: Sigmund Freud's youngest daughter who became a pioneering psychoanalyst in her own right, specializing in child psychology. The museum preserves the family's history.

josef-breuer.name: Josef Breuer
josef-breuer.bio: Austrian physician and physiologist who collaborated with Freud on 'Studies on Hysteria' (1895), making foundational contributions to the development of psychoanalysis.

danielle-spera.name: Danielle Spera
danielle-spera.bio: Austrian journalist and museum director who led the Jüdisches Museum Wien for over a decade, revitalizing its exhibitions and community engagement programs.

karl-schwarz.name: Karl Schwarz
karl-schwarz.bio: Art historian who served as the first director of the Jewish Museum Vienna when it was originally founded in 1895, building its initial collections before the Nazi closure.

werner-hanak-lettner.name: Werner Hanak-Lettner
werner-hanak-lettner.bio: Austrian curator and exhibition designer who has developed major exhibitions at the Jüdisches Museum Wien documenting Austrian Jewish history and culture.

rabbi-jacob-biderman.name: Rabbi Jacob Biderman
rabbi-jacob-biderman.bio: Chabad-Lubavitch emissary who directs Chabad of Austria and manages the Lauder Chabad Campus in Vienna, providing Jewish education and community services.

esther-jungreis-lauder.name: Georg Muzicant
esther-jungreis-lauder.bio: Austrian Jewish communal figure involved in the governance of the Lauder Chabad Campus Wien and its educational and religious programming.

rabbi-shaya-boas.name: Rabbi Shaya Boas
rabbi-shaya-boas.bio: Serves in the educational leadership of the Lauder Chabad Campus, which includes the Lauder Business School and the Lauder Chabad school system.

paul-chaim-eisenberg.name: Paul Chaim Eisenberg
paul-chaim-eisenberg.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Vienna for over three decades, becoming one of Austria's most recognizable Jewish figures and an advocate for interfaith dialogue.

affiliations.organization: Israelitische Kultusgemeinde Wien (Jewish Community of Vienna)

schlomo-hofmeister.name: Schlomo Hofmeister
schlomo-hofmeister.bio: Serves as community rabbi of the IKG Wien, leading religious services and representing the Jewish community in Vienna's public and interfaith affairs.

affiliations.organization: Israelitische Kultusgemeinde Wien (Jewish Community of Vienna)

simon-wiesenthal-mauthausen.name: Simon Wiesenthal
simon-wiesenthal-mauthausen.bio: Austrian Holocaust survivor liberated from Mauthausen in 1945 who dedicated his life to tracking down Nazi war criminals, founding the Documentation Centre in Vienna.

hans-marsalek.name: Hans Maršálek
hans-marsalek.bio: Czech-Austrian survivor of Mauthausen who became the camp's leading historian, authoring the definitive history and serving as curator of the memorial.

bertrand-perz.name: Bertrand Perz
bertrand-perz.bio: Austrian historian at the University of Vienna specializing in the history of the Mauthausen concentration camp system, a key scholarly authority on the memorial.

danielle-spera-jmv.name: Danielle Spera
danielle-spera-jmv.bio: Austrian journalist turned museum director who revitalized the Jewish Museum Vienna during her tenure, expanding its exhibitions and public programming.

karl-schwarz-jmv.name: Karl Schwarz
karl-schwarz-jmv.bio: Art historian who founded and led the original Jewish Museum Vienna in 1895, making it one of the world's first Jewish museums before its closure by the Nazis.

felicitas-heimann-jelinek.name: Felicitas Heimann-Jelinek
felicitas-heimann-jelinek.bio: Museum curator and scholar who served as chief curator at the Jewish Museum Vienna, developing groundbreaking exhibitions on Austrian Jewish history and identity.

paul-chaim-eisenberg-st.name: Paul Chaim Eisenberg
paul-chaim-eisenberg-st.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Vienna for over thirty years at the Stadttempel, the only synagogue in Vienna to survive Kristallnacht due to its concealed location within a residential block.

schlomo-hofmeister-st.name: Schlomo Hofmeister
schlomo-hofmeister-st.bio: Current community rabbi of Vienna who leads services at the Stadttempel and serves as a public representative of the Jewish community.

isidor-hirschfeld.name: Isaak Noa Mannheimer
isidor-hirschfeld.bio: Founding preacher of the Stadttempel who led the congregation from its opening in 1826, becoming the most influential Jewish religious leader in the Habsburg Empire.

simon-wiesenthal-vwi.name: Simon Wiesenthal
simon-wiesenthal-vwi.bio: Austrian Holocaust survivor and renowned Nazi hunter whose legacy inspired the founding of the Vienna Wiesenthal Institute for Holocaust Studies.

eva-kovacs.name: Éva Kovács
eva-kovacs.bio: Hungarian-Austrian historian and sociologist who has served as academic director of the VWI, leading its research programs on the Holocaust and genocide.

jochen-boehler.name: Jochen Böhler
jochen-boehler.bio: German-Austrian historian who has directed the VWI's research programs on Holocaust studies, antisemitism, and racism in contemporary Europe.

ariel-muzicant-jcv.name: Ariel Muzicant
ariel-muzicant-jcv.bio: Austrian-Jewish businessman and communal leader who served as president of Vienna's Jewish community from 1998 to 2012, revitalizing its institutions.

paul-chaim-eisenberg-jcv.name: Paul Chaim Eisenberg
paul-chaim-eisenberg-jcv.bio: Served as chief rabbi of the Jewish Community of Vienna for over three decades, widely known in Austrian public life for interfaith leadership.

paul-grosz.name: Paul Grosz
paul-grosz.bio: Austrian Jewish leader who served as president of the IKG Wien during the critical post-Cold War period, guiding the community through restitution negotiations.

philippe-blondin.name: Philippe Blondin
philippe-blondin.bio: Served as president of the board of the Musée Juif de Belgique, which documents the history and culture of Jews in Belgium from the medieval period to the present.

alexander-zanzer.name: Alexandre Zanzer
alexander-zanzer.bio: Auschwitz survivor and prominent Belgian Jewish community figure who contributed to Holocaust remembrance at the museum, killed in the 2014 terrorist attack.

yohan-benizri-mjb.name: Yohan Benizri
yohan-benizri-mjb.bio: As president of the CCOJB, connected to the governance and communal support structure of the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels.

maurice-sosnowski.name: Maurice Sosnowski
maurice-sosnowski.bio: Served as president of the CCOJB, coordinating the interests of Belgian Jewish organizations in relations with government and civil society.

affiliations.organization: Comité de Coordination des Organisations Juives de Belgique (CCOJB)

henri-bentata.name: Henri Bentata
henri-bentata.bio: Belgian-Jewish communal leader involved in CCOJB's coordination of Jewish organizational life, advocacy, and communal governance in Belgium.

affiliations.organization: Comité de Coordination des Organisations Juives de Belgique (CCOJB)

herman-van-goethem.name: Herman Van Goethem
herman-van-goethem.bio: Belgian historian and former rector of the University of Antwerp who served as founding director of the Kazerne Dossin Memorial, documenting the deportation of 25,000 Jews from Belgium.

laurence-schram.name: Laurence Schram
laurence-schram.bio: Historian and senior researcher at Kazerne Dossin specializing in the history of the Jewish deportations from Belgium, author of key works on the Mechelen transit camp.

ward-adriaens.name: Ward Adriaens
ward-adriaens.bio: Museum professional who has served in the directorship of the Kazerne Dossin Memorial, overseeing its exhibitions on the Holocaust in Belgium and human rights education.

ari-epstein-add.name: Ari Epstein
ari-epstein-add.bio: CEO of the Antwerp World Diamond Centre who represents Antwerp's diamond industry, historically dominated by Jewish traders since the 15th century.

ehud-arye-laniado.name: Ehud Arye Laniado
ehud-arye-laniado.bio: Israeli-Belgian diamond dealer and industry figure who operated in Antwerp's diamond district and was known for brokering major gemstone sales worldwide.

sylvain-goldberg.name: Sylvain Goldberg
sylvain-goldberg.bio: Veteran of the Antwerp diamond trade and leader in the diamond bourse, representing the historic Jewish presence in Antwerp's gem industry.

aron-berger.name: Aron Berger
aron-berger.bio: Prominent member of Antwerp's Orthodox Jewish community, one of Europe's most vibrant haredi communities centered around the diamond district.

rabbi-dovid-moshe-lieberman.name: Rabbi Dovid Moshe Lieberman
rabbi-dovid-moshe-lieberman.bio: Serves as chief rabbi of the Machsike Hadass community, the main Orthodox rabbinical authority in Antwerp's large and active Jewish community.

philip-carmel.name: Philip Carmel
philip-carmel.bio: Belgian-Jewish communal figure and policy advisor active in Antwerp Jewish communal affairs and the European Jewish Association.

philippe-blondin-jmb.name: Philippe Blondin
philippe-blondin-jmb.bio: Led the board of the Jewish Museum of Belgium in Brussels, which was the target of a deadly terrorist attack in May 2014.

chouna-lomponda.name: Chouna Lomponda
chouna-lomponda.bio: Served as director of the Jewish Museum of Belgium, managing its collections and exhibitions on Belgian Jewish history and culture.

joel-rubinfeld-jmb.name: Joël Rubinfeld
joel-rubinfeld-jmb.bio: Belgian-Jewish leader and former CCOJB president who has supported the Jewish Museum's role in preserving Belgian Jewish heritage.

joel-rubinfeld-ccojb.name: Joël Rubinfeld
joel-rubinfeld-ccojb.bio: Belgian-Jewish advocate and co-founder of the European Jewish Parliament who led the CCOJB's coordination of Belgian Jewish organizations.

affiliations.organization: Coordinating Committee of Jewish Organisations in Belgium (CCOJB)

maurice-sosnowski-ccojb.name: Maurice Sosnowski
maurice-sosnowski-ccojb.bio: Led the CCOJB as president, serving as the principal coordinator of Belgian Jewish communal representation and advocacy.

affiliations.organization: Coordinating Committee of Jewish Organisations in Belgium (CCOJB)

viviane-teitelbaum.name: Viviane Teitelbaum
viviane-teitelbaum.bio: Belgian-Jewish politician and communal leader who has been active in CCOJB-affiliated organizations and advocacy against antisemitism in Belgium.

affiliations.organization: Coordinating Committee of Jewish Organisations in Belgium (CCOJB)

raya-kalenova.name: Raya Kalenova
raya-kalenova.bio: Senior executive overseeing the European Jewish Congress's day-to-day operations and pan-European Jewish advocacy efforts.

nicky-oppenheimer-adc.name: Nicky Oppenheimer
nicky-oppenheimer-adc.bio: South African billionaire and former chairman of De Beers whose family's diamond empire has deep historic ties to Antwerp's diamond trading centre.

peter-meeus.name: Peter Meeus
peter-meeus.bio: Served as chairman of the Antwerp Diamond Bourse and was a prominent figure in the governance of Antwerp's diamond trading infrastructure.

jean-rosy.name: Jean Rosy
jean-rosy.bio: Led the Diamond High Council (predecessor to AWDC), overseeing the regulatory and promotional framework of Antwerp's diamond industry.

lena-posner-korosi-paideia.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
lena-posner-korosi-paideia.bio: President of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities who has supported Paideia's mission to revitalize European Jewish intellectual life.

affiliations.organization: Paideia - The European Institute for Jewish Studies

ruth-calderon.name: Ruth Calderon
ruth-calderon.bio: Israeli Talmud scholar, educator, and former Knesset member who has contributed to Paideia's academic programs on Jewish textual literacy in secular contexts.

affiliations.organization: Paideia - The European Institute for Jewish Studies

daniel-libeskind-paideia.name: Daniel Libeskind
daniel-libeskind-paideia.bio: World-renowned architect of the Jewish Museum Berlin who has participated in Paideia's programs exploring European Jewish culture and identity.

affiliations.organization: Paideia - The European Institute for Jewish Studies

lena-posner-korosi-jfs.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
lena-posner-korosi-jfs.bio: Prominent leader of Swedish Jewry who has served as president of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, closely connected to the Stockholm congregation.

morton-narrowe.name: Morton Narrowe
morton-narrowe.bio: American-born rabbi who served as chief rabbi of Stockholm for over 35 years, becoming Sweden's most prominent Jewish religious leader.

michael-bart.name: Michael Bart
michael-bart.bio: Swedish Jewish communal figure who has held leadership positions within the Judiska Församlingen i Stockholm, managing congregational affairs.

aron-verstandig-jm.name: Aron Verständig
aron-verstandig-jm.bio: President of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, connected to the governance of the Jewish Museum in Stockholm.

hanna-sjoberg.name: Hanna Sjöberg
hanna-sjoberg.bio: Curator at the Judiska Museet who has developed exhibitions documenting the history and cultural contributions of Jews in Sweden since the 18th century.

maija-runcis.name: Maija Runcis
maija-runcis.bio: Swedish historian who has contributed scholarly expertise to the Jewish Museum in Stockholm's documentation of Swedish Jewish history and heritage.

lena-posner-korosi-oc.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
lena-posner-korosi-oc.bio: Led the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities as its president, representing Sweden's approximately 15,000 Jews in communal and governmental affairs.

affiliations.organization: Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities

morton-narrowe-oc.name: Morton Narrowe
morton-narrowe-oc.bio: Longtime chief rabbi of Stockholm who served as the senior rabbinical figure connected to the Official Council and Swedish Jewish religious life.

affiliations.organization: Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities

isak-reichel.name: Isak Reichel
isak-reichel.bio: Served as secretary-general of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, managing its administrative functions and governmental relations.

affiliations.organization: Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities

morten-kjaerum.name: Morten Kjaerum
morten-kjaerum.bio: Danish human rights expert who served as director of the Raoul Wallenberg Institute in Lund, Sweden, and previously led the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights.

anna-petrig.name: Anna Petrig
anna-petrig.bio: International law scholar who has contributed to the Raoul Wallenberg Institute's research on human rights, based at Lund University.

guy-von-dardel.name: Guy von Dardel
guy-von-dardel.bio: Physicist and half-brother of Raoul Wallenberg who spent decades campaigning for information about Wallenberg's fate and supporting institutions honoring his legacy.

fredrik-vilhelm-scholander.name: Fredrik Vilhelm Scholander
fredrik-vilhelm-scholander.bio: Leading Swedish architect who designed the Great Synagogue of Stockholm, completed in 1870 in a Moorish-Egyptian revival style.

morton-narrowe-gs.name: Morton Narrowe
morton-narrowe-gs.bio: American-born rabbi who served as chief rabbi at the Great Synagogue of Stockholm for over 35 years, the longest-serving chief rabbi in Swedish history.

marcus-ehrenpreis.name: Marcus Ehrenpreis
marcus-ehrenpreis.bio: Galician-born rabbi and author who served as chief rabbi of Stockholm for nearly four decades, becoming a major figure in Swedish cultural and intellectual life.

pontus-ljunghill-jms.name: Pontus Ljunghill
pontus-ljunghill-jms.bio: Museum director leading the Jewish Museum in Stockholm, which documents the history of Jewish life in Sweden from the 18th century to the present.

aron-verstandig-jms.name: Aron Verständig
aron-verstandig-jms.bio: Chairman of the Official Council of Swedish Jewish Communities, connected to the institutional support of the Jewish Museum Stockholm.

hanna-sjoberg-jms.name: Hanna Sjöberg
hanna-sjoberg-jms.bio: Museum curator involved in developing exhibitions at the Jewish Museum Stockholm on Swedish Jewish identity, immigration history, and cultural heritage.

lena-posner-korosi-jcs.name: Lena Posner-Körösi
lena-posner-korosi-jcs.bio: Prominent Swedish Jewish leader who served as president of the Official Council and has been deeply connected to the Stockholm Jewish community.

morton-narrowe-jcs.name: Morton Narrowe
morton-narrowe-jcs.bio: Served as chief rabbi of the Jewish Community of Stockholm for over 35 years, shaping Swedish Jewish religious life from 1965 to 2001.

isak-reichel-jcs.name: Isak Reichel
isak-reichel-jcs.bio: Has served as secretary-general of Swedish Jewish communal organizations, contributing to the administrative governance of the Stockholm community.

albert-bonnier-sr.name: Albert Bonnier Sr.
albert-bonnier-sr.bio: Swedish publisher of Jewish German origin who founded the Bonnier publishing house in 1837, building it into one of Scandinavia's most influential media companies.

carl-johan-bonnier.name: Carl-Johan Bonnier
carl-johan-bonnier.bio: Sixth-generation member of the Bonnier family who served as chairman of the Bonnier Group, overseeing its media portfolio spanning publishing, broadcasting, and digital media.

albert-bonnier-jr.name: Albert Bonnier Jr.
albert-bonnier-jr.bio: Third-generation Bonnier publisher who led the Albert Bonniers Förlag publishing house through the mid-20th century, expanding its literary catalog.

ludwig-forster.name: Ludwig Förster
ludwig-forster.bio: Viennese architect who designed the Dohány Street Synagogue in Budapest, completed in 1859 as the largest synagogue in Europe in a Romantic-Moorish style.

robert-frolich-ds.name: Róbert Frölich
robert-frolich-ds.bio: Serves as chief rabbi of Hungary at the Dohány Street Synagogue, the seat of the Neolog (Reform) Jewish congregation and the largest synagogue in Europe.

peter-feldmajer.name: Péter Feldmájer
peter-feldmajer.bio: Hungarian-Jewish communal leader who served as president of the Federation of Hungarian Jewish Communities, overseeing the restoration of the Dohány synagogue complex.

imre-varga.name: Imre Varga
imre-varga.bio: Hungarian sculptor who created the Raoul Wallenberg Memorial in Budapest, a bronze figure standing near the former Swedish Embassy.

per-anger.name: Per Anger
per-anger.bio: Swedish diplomat who worked alongside Raoul Wallenberg in Budapest in 1944, helping save Hungarian Jews and later advocating for information about Wallenberg's fate.

carl-lutz.name: Carl Lutz
carl-lutz.bio: Swiss vice-consul in Budapest who, like Wallenberg, saved tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews during the Holocaust through protective documents and safe houses.

robert-frolich-maz.name: Róbert Frölich
robert-frolich-maz.bio: Serves as chief rabbi of the Neolog Jewish community in Hungary, the senior rabbinical figure within the MAZSIHISZ federation.

gusztav-zoltai.name: Gusztáv Zoltai
gusztav-zoltai.bio: Longtime executive director of MAZSIHISZ who managed the day-to-day affairs of Hungarian Jewish communal life for decades.

peter-feldmajer-maz.name: Péter Feldmájer
peter-feldmajer-maz.bio: Hungarian Jewish leader who served as president of MAZSIHISZ, leading the community through the post-Communist transition period and synagogue restoration efforts.

andras-heisler-hjm.name: András Heisler
andras-heisler-hjm.bio: As president of the Federation of Hungarian Jewish Communities, oversees the Hungarian Jewish Museum and Archives located within the Dohány synagogue complex.

robert-frolich-hjm.name: Róbert Frölich
robert-frolich-hjm.bio: Chief rabbi of Hungary whose work at the Dohány synagogue complex encompasses the Hungarian Jewish Museum's role in preserving Hungarian Jewish heritage.

ilona-seifert.name: Ilona Seifert
ilona-seifert.bio: Museum professional involved in curating the Hungarian Jewish Museum's collections of ceremonial objects, historical documents, and Holocaust memorial artifacts.

gyula-pauer.name: Gyula Pauer
gyula-pauer.bio: Hungarian sculptor who created the sixty pairs of cast-iron shoes along the Danube bank in 2005, memorializing thousands of Jews shot into the river in 1944-45.

barnabas-hollo.name: Barnabás Holló
barnabas-hollo.bio: Hungarian architect who contributed to the design and installation of the Shoes on the Danube Bank memorial along the Pest riverfront.

gabor-szegedi.name: Gábor Szegedi
gabor-szegedi.bio: Hungarian public figure involved in promoting Budapest Holocaust memorials including the Shoes on the Danube, contributing to their recognition as major memorial sites.

andras-heisler-hjhf.name: András Heisler
andras-heisler-hjhf.bio: As president of MAZSIHISZ, closely connected to the Hungarian Jewish Heritage Foundation's work preserving synagogues and cultural sites across Hungary.

rudolf-klein.name: Rudolf Klein
rudolf-klein.bio: Hungarian-Israeli architectural historian who has documented and advocated for the preservation of synagogues and Jewish architectural heritage in Hungary.

robert-frolich-hjhf.name: Róbert Frölich
robert-frolich-hjhf.bio: Chief rabbi of Hungary who provides religious guidance and support to heritage preservation efforts for Hungarian Jewish cultural sites and communities.

andras-heisler-ort.name: András Heisler
andras-heisler-ort.bio: President of MAZSIHISZ who supports ORT Hungary's educational mission within the broader framework of Hungarian Jewish communal institutions.

vera-szoke.name: Vera Szőke
vera-szoke.bio: Educator involved in directing ORT Hungary's programs providing technology education and vocational training within Hungary's Jewish community.

ludwig-forster-dss.name: Ludwig Förster
ludwig-forster-dss.bio: Viennese architect who designed the Dohány Street Synagogue, completed in 1859 in a Moorish Revival style, making it Europe's largest synagogue.

frigyes-feszl.name: Frigyes Feszl
frigyes-feszl.bio: Hungarian architect who designed the ornate interior decorations of the Dohány Street Synagogue, contributing to its distinctive Romantic-Moorish aesthetic.

peter-feldmajer-dss.name: Péter Feldmájer
peter-feldmajer-dss.bio: Led the Federation of Hungarian Jewish Communities during the major restoration of the Dohány Street Synagogue complex in the 1990s.

ishak-ibrahimzadeh-tjc.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
ishak-ibrahimzadeh-tjc.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish Community, managing its communal affairs and representing Turkey's approximately 15,000 Jews, mostly based in Istanbul.

jak-kamhi.name: Jak Kamhi
jak-kamhi.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist and founder of the Quincentennial Foundation who has been a leading figure in promoting Turkish-Jewish heritage and interfaith dialogue.

bensiyon-pinto.name: Bensiyon Pinto
bensiyon-pinto.bio: Served as president of the Turkish Jewish Community, leading communal governance and representation during a period of community revitalization.

ishak-haleva-tmc.name: İshak Haleva
ishak-haleva-tmc.bio: Serves as Hakham Bashi (Chief Rabbi) of Turkey since 2002, the spiritual leader of the Turkish Sephardic Jewish community.

jak-kamhi-tmc.name: Jak Kamhi
jak-kamhi-tmc.bio: Prominent Turkish-Jewish businessman who founded Profilo Holding and the Quincentennial Foundation, a leading advocate for Turkish-Jewish heritage.

silvyo-ovadya-tmc.name: Silvyo Ovadya
silvyo-ovadya-tmc.bio: Served as president of the Turkish Jewish Community and chairman of the Quincentennial Foundation, representing Turkish Jewry in public affairs.

naim-guleryuz-mtj.name: Naim Güleryüz
naim-guleryuz-mtj.bio: Turkish-Jewish historian who documented the 500-year history of Jews in the Ottoman Empire and Turkey, serving as historian for the Museum of Turkish Jews.

jak-kamhi-mtj.name: Jak Kamhi
jak-kamhi-mtj.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist who founded the Quincentennial Foundation in 1992 to commemorate 500 years of Jewish life in Turkey, establishing the museum.

silvyo-ovadya-mtj.name: Silvyo Ovadya
silvyo-ovadya-mtj.bio: Led the Quincentennial Foundation that operates the Museum of Turkish Jews, promoting awareness of Sephardic Jewish heritage in Turkey.

jak-kamhi-ns.name: Jak Kamhi
jak-kamhi-ns.bio: Prominent Turkish-Jewish industrialist and community leader closely connected to the Neve Shalom synagogue, which was targeted in terrorist attacks in 1986 and 2003.

david-asseo-ns.name: David Asseo
david-asseo-ns.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Turkey before İshak Haleva, leading the community from the Neve Shalom synagogue, the main synagogue of Istanbul.

ishak-ibrahimzadeh-ns.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
ishak-ibrahimzadeh-ns.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish Community who oversees Neve Shalom synagogue, Istanbul's principal Sephardic house of worship.

ishak-haleva-as.name: İshak Haleva
ishak-haleva-as.bio: Chief Rabbi of Turkey who oversees the religious life of historic Istanbul synagogues including the Ahrida, one of the oldest in the city dating to the 15th century.

naim-guleryuz-as.name: Naim Güleryüz
naim-guleryuz-as.bio: Turkish-Jewish historian who has documented the history of the Ahrida Synagogue, one of Istanbul's most important Romaniot and Sephardic heritage sites.

ishak-ibrahimzadeh-as.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
ishak-ibrahimzadeh-as.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish community responsible for the preservation and maintenance of historic Istanbul synagogues including the Ahrida.

jak-kamhi-qfm.name: Jak Kamhi
jak-kamhi-qfm.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist who founded the Quincentennial Foundation in 1992 to commemorate 500 years since the Ottoman welcome of Sephardic Jews expelled from Spain.

silvyo-ovadya-qfm.name: Silvyo Ovadya
silvyo-ovadya-qfm.bio: Former president of the Turkish Jewish Community who served as chairman of the Quincentennial Foundation, overseeing its museum and cultural programs.

ishak-ibrahimzadeh-qfm.name: Ishak Ibrahimzadeh
ishak-ibrahimzadeh-qfm.bio: President of the Turkish Jewish Community who supports the Quincentennial Foundation Museum's mission to document 500 years of Jewish life in Turkey.

david-asseo.name: David Asseo
david-asseo.bio: Served as chief rabbi (Hakham Bashi) of Turkey before İshak Haleva, leading the Sephardic community's religious affairs.

rafael-saban.name: Rafael Saban
rafael-saban.bio: Served as chief rabbi of Turkey in the mid-20th century, guiding the Sephardic community through a period of modernization and demographic change.

jak-kamhi-cr.name: Jak Kamhi
jak-kamhi-cr.bio: Leading Turkish-Jewish industrialist and communal figure who has supported the chief rabbinate's institutional and cultural activities.

jak-kamhi-qf.name: Jak Kamhi
jak-kamhi-qf.bio: Turkish-Jewish industrialist and founder of Profilo Holding who established the Quincentennial Foundation in 1992 to celebrate and preserve Turkish-Jewish heritage.

naim-guleryuz-qf.name: Naim Güleryüz
naim-guleryuz-qf.bio: Leading Turkish-Jewish historian who has documented the history of the Jewish community in Turkey for the Quincentennial Foundation's publications and museum.

ishak-haleva-qf.name: İshak Haleva
ishak-haleva-qf.bio: Chief Rabbi of Turkey who supports the Quincentennial Foundation's mission to preserve the legacy of 500 years of Jewish life in Turkey.

andre-azoulay-ccim.name: André Azoulay
andre-azoulay-ccim.bio: Jewish Moroccan businessman and senior adviser to King Mohammed VI who champions interfaith dialogue and the preservation of Moroccan Jewish heritage.

affiliations.organization: Conseil des Communautés Israélites du Maroc

jacky-kadoch.name: Jacky Kadoch
jacky-kadoch.bio: Moroccan Jewish communal figure involved in the governance of the Council of Israelite Communities, helping maintain Jewish institutional life in Morocco.

affiliations.organization: Conseil des Communautés Israélites du Maroc

simon-levy-ccim.name: Simon Levy
simon-levy-ccim.bio: Moroccan-Jewish scholar and founder of the Museum of Moroccan Judaism in Casablanca, who documented the history of Jewish life in Morocco.

affiliations.organization: Conseil des Communautés Israélites du Maroc

simon-levy.name: Simon Levy
simon-levy.bio: Moroccan-Jewish professor and historian who founded the Museum of Moroccan Judaism in Casablanca in 1997, the only Jewish museum in the Arab world.

serge-berdugo-mmj.name: Serge Berdugo
serge-berdugo-mmj.bio: Secretary-general of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco who has supported the museum as a centerpiece of Moroccan Jewish heritage preservation.

andre-azoulay-mmj.name: André Azoulay
andre-azoulay-mmj.bio: Senior adviser to King Mohammed VI and a champion of Moroccan Jewish heritage preservation, supporting the museum's mission of documenting Jewish life in Morocco.

serge-berdugo-bd.name: Serge Berdugo
serge-berdugo-bd.bio: Secretary-general of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco who supports Bayt Dakira's mission of preserving Jewish heritage in Essaouira.

audrey-azoulay.name: Audrey Azoulay
audrey-azoulay.bio: Daughter of André Azoulay, French-Moroccan diplomat serving as UNESCO Director-General, connected to the family's commitment to Moroccan-Jewish heritage preservation.

tahar-ben-jelloun.name: Tahar Ben Jelloun
tahar-ben-jelloun.bio: Moroccan-French author and intellectual who has supported initiatives preserving Morocco's Jewish-Muslim coexistence heritage, including the Essaouira projects.

serge-berdugo-cjc.name: Serge Berdugo
serge-berdugo-cjc.bio: Former Moroccan Minister of Tourism who has served as secretary-general of the Council, the central body representing Morocco's Jewish communities.

affiliations.organization: Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco

jacky-kadoch-cjc.name: Jacky Kadoch
jacky-kadoch-cjc.bio: Active in the governance of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco, contributing to the maintenance of Jewish communal institutions across the country.

affiliations.organization: Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco

simon-levy-cjc.name: Simon Levy
simon-levy-cjc.bio: Moroccan-Jewish historian whose scholarly work and founding of the Museum of Moroccan Judaism contributed to the Council's heritage preservation mission.

affiliations.organization: Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco

andre-azoulay-rhp.name: André Azoulay
andre-azoulay-rhp.bio: Jewish Moroccan royal adviser and prominent Essaouira native who has championed the preservation of the city's Jewish heritage sites including the Pinto synagogue.

serge-berdugo-rhp.name: Serge Berdugo
serge-berdugo-rhp.bio: Secretary-general of the Council of Jewish Communities of Morocco who supports the preservation of historic synagogues including the Rabbi Haim Pinto Synagogue in Essaouira.

rabbi-yoshiyahu-pinto.name: Rabbi Yoshiyahu Pinto
rabbi-yoshiyahu-pinto.bio: Prominent Israeli-Moroccan rabbi and descendant of Rabbi Haim Pinto who leads an international following and maintains the family's spiritual legacy connected to Essaouira.

andre-azoulay-cjht.name: André Azoulay
andre-azoulay-cjht.bio: Senior adviser to King Mohammed VI and champion of Moroccan Jewish heritage who has supported the development of Jewish heritage tourism in Casablanca.

zhor-rehihil-cjht.name: Zhor Rehihil
zhor-rehihil-cjht.bio: Curator of the Museum of Moroccan Judaism in Casablanca who contributes expertise to the preservation and presentation of Jewish heritage sites in the city.

simon-levy-cjht.name: Simon Levy
simon-levy-cjht.bio: Moroccan-Jewish scholar whose research on Jewish life in Casablanca and across Morocco laid the groundwork for heritage trail initiatives.

andre-azoulay-cim.name: André Azoulay
andre-azoulay-cim.bio: Prominent Moroccan-Jewish adviser to King Mohammed VI who works closely with the Council on matters of Jewish heritage preservation and interfaith relations.

affiliations.organization: Conseil des Communautes Israelites du Maroc

jacky-kadoch-cim.name: Jacky Kadoch
jacky-kadoch-cim.bio: Moroccan Jewish figure active in the Council's governance, helping represent and maintain Jewish communal institutions across Morocco.

affiliations.organization: Conseil des Communautes Israelites du Maroc

simon-levy-cim.name: Simon Levy
simon-levy-cim.bio: Moroccan-Jewish professor and social activist who founded the Casablanca Jewish museum and contributed to the Council's cultural preservation mission.

affiliations.organization: Conseil des Communautes Israelites du Maroc

matteo-ricci.name: Matteo Ricci
matteo-ricci.bio: Italian Jesuit priest who in 1605 became the first Westerner to document the Kaifeng Jewish community, providing invaluable historical records of their practices and traditions.

ai-tian.name: Ai Tian
ai-tian.bio: Kaifeng Jewish scholar who traveled to Beijing in 1605 and met Matteo Ricci, becoming the first known contact between the Kaifeng Jews and the Western world.

timothy-richard.name: Timothy Richard
timothy-richard.bio: Welsh Baptist missionary in China who documented the Kaifeng Jewish community in the late 19th century, helping bring international scholarly attention to their heritage.

ho-feng-shan.name: Ho Feng-Shan
ho-feng-shan.bio: Chinese consul-general in Vienna who issued thousands of visas to Jewish refugees fleeing the Holocaust, enabling them to escape to Shanghai. Recognized as Righteous Among the Nations by Yad Vashem.

affiliations.role: Chinese Diplomat & Righteous Among the Nations

david-kranzler.name: David Kranzler
david-kranzler.bio: American historian and author of 'Japanese, Nazis & Jews: The Jewish Refugee Community of Shanghai 1938-1945,' a foundational work on the Shanghai Jewish refugee experience.

victor-sassoon.name: Victor Sassoon
victor-sassoon.bio: Sir Victor Sassoon, 3rd Baronet, built the iconic Cathay Hotel (Sassoon House) on the Bund in Shanghai in 1929, making it the city's most prestigious hotel and a symbol of cosmopolitan Shanghai.

david-sassoon-founder.name: David Sassoon
david-sassoon-founder.bio: Founder of the Sassoon trading dynasty who established the family's vast commercial empire across Asia. His descendants, including Victor Sassoon, shaped Shanghai's architectural landscape.

george-leopold-wilson.name: George Leopold Wilson
george-leopold-wilson.bio: British architect with Palmer & Turner who designed Sassoon House (Cathay Hotel) on the Shanghai Bund, creating one of the most iconic Art Deco buildings in Asia.

david-sassoon-patriarch.name: David Sassoon
david-sassoon-patriarch.bio: Born in Baghdad in 1792, David Sassoon fled to Bombay and built a vast trading empire spanning India, China, and the Far East, earning the family the title 'Rothschilds of the East.'

albert-abdallah-sassoon.name: Albert Abdullah David Sassoon
albert-abdallah-sassoon.bio: Son of David Sassoon who expanded the family's enterprises, built synagogues and schools in Bombay, and became the first Indian-born person to be made an English baronet.

ma-huateng.name: Ma Huateng
ma-huateng.bio: Known as Pony Ma, he co-founded Tencent in 1998 and built it into one of the world's largest technology conglomerates, overseeing WeChat, QQ, and a massive gaming portfolio.

zhang-zhidong.name: Zhang Zhidong
zhang-zhidong.bio: One of the five co-founders of Tencent who served as Chief Technology Officer, playing a key role in building the company's core technology infrastructure and early product development.

martin-lau.name: Martin Lau
martin-lau.bio: Joined Tencent in 2005 and became President, driving the company's investment strategy including stakes in Epic Games, Spotify, and many other global firms.

ilya-khrzhanovsky.name: Ilya Khrzhanovsky
ilya-khrzhanovsky.bio: Russian-born film director who served as artistic director of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center, developing its innovative but controversial memorial concepts.

ronald-lauder-byhmc.name: Ronald Lauder
ronald-lauder-byhmc.bio: American billionaire and World Jewish Congress president who has supported the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center's mission to commemorate the massacre of over 33,000 Jews in 1941.

yana-barinova.name: Yana Barinova
yana-barinova.bio: Served as CEO of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center, managing its operations and the development of the memorial complex in Kyiv.

meylakh-sheykhet-gr.name: Meylakh Sheykhet
meylakh-sheykhet-gr.bio: Ukrainian Jewish leader and representative of the Union of Councils for Soviet Jews who has championed the preservation and memorialization of the Golden Rose Synagogue ruins in Lviv.

boris-lozhkin-gr.name: Boris Lozhkin
boris-lozhkin-gr.bio: President of the Jewish Confederation of Ukraine who has supported efforts to preserve and memorialize Ukrainian Jewish heritage sites including the Golden Rose Synagogue.

nachman-krochmal.name: Nachman Krochmal
nachman-krochmal.bio: Galician Jewish philosopher and historian from Lviv who was one of the founders of the Wissenschaft des Judentums movement and connected to Lviv's Jewish intellectual life.

ihor-kolomoyskyi.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
ihor-kolomoyskyi.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish billionaire who co-funded the construction of the Menorah Center in Dnipro, the world's largest Jewish community center, opened in 2012.

rabbi-shmuel-kaminezki.name: Rabbi Shmuel Kaminezki
rabbi-shmuel-kaminezki.bio: Chabad rabbi serving as chief rabbi of Dnipro who provides spiritual leadership at the Menorah Center, a seven-branched building symbolizing the menorah.

jonathan-markovitch.name: Jonathan Markovitch
jonathan-markovitch.bio: Has served in the leadership of the Menorah Center in Dnipro, managing its community facilities, museum, and cultural programming.

rabbi-nathan-of-breslov.name: Rabbi Nathan of Breslov
rabbi-nathan-of-breslov.bio: Chief disciple of Rabbi Nachman of Breslov who compiled and preserved his master's teachings, establishing the tradition of annual pilgrimage to Nachman's grave in Uman.

rabbi-nachman-burstein.name: Rabbi Nachman Burstein
rabbi-nachman-burstein.bio: Breslov elder and leader who helped revive the annual Rosh Hashanah pilgrimage to Uman after the fall of the Soviet Union, when gatherings swelled from hundreds to tens of thousands.

rabbi-eliezer-shlomo-schick.name: Rabbi Eliezer Shlomo Schick
rabbi-eliezer-shlomo-schick.bio: Prominent Breslov rabbi and author who led a large following and was instrumental in organizing the annual Uman pilgrimage gatherings.

vadim-rabinovich.name: Vadim Rabinovich
vadim-rabinovich.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish businessman and politician who co-founded the Jewish Confederation of Ukraine and served as a member of the Ukrainian parliament.

josef-zissels-jcu.name: Josef Zissels
josef-zissels-jcu.bio: Chairman of the Association of Jewish Organizations and Communities of Ukraine (VAAD) and a leading Ukrainian Jewish communal figure and human rights activist.

ihor-kolomoyskyi-jcu.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
ihor-kolomoyskyi-jcu.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish billionaire and former governor of Dnipropetrovsk Oblast who has supported Jewish communal institutions in Ukraine.

boris-lozhkin-ujcu.name: Boris Lozhkin
boris-lozhkin-ujcu.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish businessman and former head of the Presidential Administration of Ukraine who serves as president of the United Jewish Community of Ukraine.

josef-zissels-ujcu.name: Josef Zissels
josef-zissels-ujcu.bio: Longtime Ukrainian Jewish leader and chairman of VAAD who participates in the United Jewish Community's coordination of Ukrainian Jewry.

ihor-kolomoyskyi-ujcu.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
ihor-kolomoyskyi-ujcu.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish billionaire and co-founder of PrivatBank who has been a major financial supporter of Jewish communal organizations in Ukraine.

vadim-rabinovich-ujc.name: Vadim Rabinovich
vadim-rabinovich-ujc.bio: Ukrainian-Jewish businessman and politician who has led the Ukrainian Jewish Confederation, representing Jewish community interests in Ukrainian public life.

josef-zissels-ujc.name: Josef Zissels
josef-zissels-ujc.bio: Chairman of the Association of Jewish Organizations and Communities of Ukraine, a key leader in the umbrella structure of Ukrainian Jewish communal organizations.

ihor-kolomoyskyi-ujc.name: Ihor Kolomoyskyi
ihor-kolomoyskyi-ujc.bio: Billionaire businessman who has supported Ukrainian Jewish institutions and is one of the most prominent Jewish figures in Ukrainian public life.

rabbi-judah-loew-josefov.name: Rabbi Judah Loew ben Bezalel
rabbi-judah-loew-josefov.bio: Known as the Maharal of Prague, a renowned Talmudist and philosopher connected to the legend of the Golem, who led the Jewish community in Josefov.

mordechai-maisel.name: Mordechai Maisel
mordechai-maisel.bio: Wealthy Jewish financier and mayor of Prague's Jewish quarter who funded the construction of synagogues, streets, and the first Jewish town hall in Josefov.

karol-sidon-ons.name: Karol Sidon
karol-sidon-ons.bio: Czech author and rabbi who served as chief rabbi of Prague and the Czech Republic, leading services at the Old-New Synagogue, Europe's oldest active synagogue.

affiliations.role: Former Chief Rabbi of Czech Republic

mordechai-maisel-ons.name: Mordechai Maisel
mordechai-maisel-ons.bio: Renaissance-era Jewish financier and philanthropist who supported the synagogues and institutions of Prague's Jewish quarter during the Maharal's era.

avigdor-kara.name: Avigdor Kara
avigdor-kara.bio: Medieval rabbi and poet of the Prague Jewish community whose gravestone in the Old Jewish Cemetery is the oldest preserved, and who witnessed the 1389 Easter pogrom.

tomas-kraus.name: Tomáš Kraus
tomas-kraus.bio: Longtime executive director of the Federation of Jewish Communities in the Czech Republic, managing communal affairs and representing Czech Jewry internationally.

affiliations.organization: Federace židovských obcí v České republice

karol-sidon-fed.name: Karol Sidon
karol-sidon-fed.bio: Czech writer and rabbi who served as chief rabbi of the Czech Republic, providing religious leadership within the federation's institutional framework.

affiliations.organization: Federace židovských obcí v České republice

david-peter-synagogue.name: David Peter
david-peter-synagogue.bio: Czech Jewish communal leader who has contributed to the federation's work in rebuilding and sustaining Jewish community life in the post-Communist Czech Republic.

affiliations.organization: Federace židovských obcí v České republice

vojtech-blodig.name: Vojtěch Blodig
vojtech-blodig.bio: Longtime deputy director and historian at the Terezín Memorial who has authored major studies on the Theresienstadt ghetto and its role in the Holocaust.

hans-krasa.name: Hans Krása
